exercised or discharged by it, shall be exercised and discharged by any officer or authority subordinate to it” were omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
205	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE COCONUT COMMITTEE ACT, 1944</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center">THE COCONUT COMMITTEE ACT, 1944</p><p align="center">(ACT NO. X OF 1944)</p><p align="right">[31st March, 1944]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to provide for financing a Committee for the improvement and development of the cultivation, marketing and utilisation of coconuts in Bangladesh. 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for financing a Committee for the improvement and development of the cultivation, marketing and utilisation of coconuts in Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title and extent</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the Coconut Committee Act, 1944.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definitions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “Collector” means the officer appointed by the Government to perform in any specified area the duties of a Collector under the provisions of this Act and the rules made thereunder, and includes any officer subordinate to that officer whom he may by order in writing authorise to perform his duties under those provisions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “the Committee” means the Bangladesh Food and Agriculture Committee set up under sub section (1) of section 5A of the Agricultural Produce Cess Act, 1940, or any body which replaces the said Committee under sub section (2) of that section;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) “mill” means any place in which copra is crushed for the extraction of oil, which is a factory as defined in section 2 of the 2[ Factories Act, 1965];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Imposition of coconut cess</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) There shall be levied and collected, as a cess for the purposes of this Act, on all copra consumed in any mill in Bangladesh, whether produced in or imported from outside Bangladesh, a duty of excise at such rate, not exceeding 3[ twenty-five poisha] per cwt., as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, fix in this behalf :</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Government may by notification in the official Gazette vary the rate at which the duty of excise shall be levied and collected.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) On the last day of each month, or as soon thereafter as may be convenient, the proceeds of the duty recovered during that month shall, after deduction of the expenses, if any, of collection and recovery, be paid to the Committee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The proceeds of the duties recovered since the fifteenth day of August 1947 after deducting expenses of collection and recovery if any shall be paid to the Committee forthwith.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. [Constitution of Indian Coconut Committee.- Omitted by section 7 of the Coconut Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XVIII of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. [Incorporation of the Committee.- Omitted by section 7 of the Coconut Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XVIII of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. [Vacancies.- Omitted by section 7 of the Coconut Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XVIII of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. [President of Committee, Secretary, Sub committees and staff.- Omitted by section 7 of the Coconut Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XVIII of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. [Appointment of officers.- Omitted by section 7 of the Coconut Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XVIII of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Functions of the Committee</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) The Committee shall take such measures as it may consider necessary or expedient for the improvement and development of the cultivation and marketing of coconuts and of the production, utilisation and marketing of copra, coconut oil and coconut poonac.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, the Committee may defray expenditure involved in-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) undertaking, assisting or encouraging agricultural, industrial, technological and economic research;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the supply of technical advice to growers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) encouraging the adoption of improved methods in cultivation;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) carrying on such propaganda in the interests of the coconut industry as may be necessary;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) collecting statistics from growers, dealers, millers and other sources on all relevant matters bearing on the industry;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) fixing grade standards of copra and its products;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) recommending the maximum and minimum prices to be fixed for copra;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) advising on all matters which require attention for the development of the industry;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) improving the marketing of coconuts and suggesting suitable measures to prevent unfair competition;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) assisting in the control of insects and other pests and diseases of coconut trees;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) promoting and encouraging co operative efforts among the coconut growers and in the coconut industries;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l) adopting such measures as may be practicable for assuring remunerative returns to growers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m) maintaining and assisting in the maintenance of such institutes, farms and stations as it may consider necessary;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n) adopting any other measures or performing any other duties which it may be required by the Government to adopt or perform or which the Committee itself may think necessary or advisable in order to carry out the purposes of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Delivery of monthly returns</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) The owner of every mill shall furnish to the Collector on or before the 7th day of each month, a return stating the total amount of copra consumed in the mill during the preceding month, together with such further information in regard thereto as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no return shall be required in regard to copra consumed before the commencement of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every such return shall be made in such form and shall be verified in such manner as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Collection of cess by Collector</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) On receiving any return made under section 10, the Collector shall assess the amount of the duty payable under section 3 in respect of the period to which the return relates, and if the amount has not already been paid shall cause a notice to be served upon the owner of the mill requiring him to make payment of the amount assessed within thirty days of the service of the notice.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If the owner of any mill fails to furnish in due time the return referred to in sub section (1) of section 10 or furnishes a return which the Collector has reason to believe is incorrect or defective, the Collector shall assess the amount, if any, payable by him in such manner, as may be prescribed, and the provisions of sub section (1) shall thereupon apply as if such assessment had been made on the basis of a return furnished by the owner:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that in the case of a return which he has reason to believe is incorrect or defective, the Collector shall not assess the duty at an amount higher than that at which it is assessable on the basis of the return without giving to the owner a reasonable opportunity of proving the correctness and completeness of the return.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A notice under sub section (1) may be served on the owner of a mill either by post or by delivering it or tendering it to the owner or his agent at the mill.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Finality of assessment and recovery of unpaid duty</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. (1) Any owner of a mill who is aggrieved by an assessment made under section 11 may, within three months of service of the notice referred to in sub section (1) of that section, apply to the District Judge, for the cancellation or modification of the assessment and, on such application, the said Judge may cancel or modify the assessment and order the refund to such owner of the whole or part, as the case may be, of any amount paid thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The decision under sub section (1) of the District Judge shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Any sum recoverable under section 11 may be recovered as an arrear of land revenue.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to inspect mills and take copies of records and accounts</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) The Collector or any officer empowered by general or special order of the Government in this behalf shall have free access at all reasonable times during working hours to any mill or to any part of any mill.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Collector or any such officer may at any time during working hours, with or without notice to the owner, examine the purchase, sale and stock records and accounts of any mill and take copies of or extracts from all or any of the said records or accounts for the purpose of testing the accuracy of any return or of informing himself as to the particulars regarding which information is required for the purposes of this Act or any rules made thereunder:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing in this section shall be deemed to authorise the examination of any description or formulae of any trade process.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Information acquired to be confidential</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) All such copies and extracts and all information acquired by a Collector or any other officer from an inspection of any mill or warehouse or from any return submitted under this Act shall be treated as confidential.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If the Collector or any such officer discloses to any person other than a superior officer any such information as aforesaid without the previous sanction of the Government, he shall be punishable with imprisonment which may extend to six months and shall also be liable to fine:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to the disclosure of any such information for the purposes of a prosecution in respect of the making of a false return under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. [Application of proceeds of duty.- Omitted by section 8 of the Indian Coconut Committee (Amendment.) Act, 1946 (Act No. XV of 1946).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. [Keeping and auditing of accounts. Omitted by section 10 of the Coconut Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XVIII of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. [Dissolution of Committee.- Omitted by section 10 of the Coconut Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XVIII of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power of the Government to make rule</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. (1) The Government may make rules for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) [Omitted by section 11 of the Coconut Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XVIII of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalty for contravention of rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4[ 18A. Rules made under section 18 may provide that a breach of any of them shall be punishable with fine not exceeding one thousand 5[ Taka].]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. [Power of the Committee to make regulations.- Omitted by section 12 of the Coconut Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XVIII of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Publication of rules and regulations</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. All rules made under section 18 shall be published in the official Gazette.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">___________________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, the words “Bangladesh” and “Government” were substituted for the words “Pakistan” and “Central Government” respectively by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words, comma and figure “Factories Act, 1965” were substituted for the words, comma and figure “Factories Act, 1934” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The words “twenty-five poisha” were substituted for the words “four Annas” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 Section 18A was inserted by section 2 of the Coconut and Oilseeds Committees Acts (Amendment) Ordinance, 1962 (Ordinance No. XXV of 1962)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The word “Taka” was substituted for the word “rupees” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
206	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE COMMISSIONS OF INQUIRY ACT, 1956 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE COMMISSIONS OF INQUIRY ACT, 1956</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. VI OF 1956)</p><p align="right">[11th April, 1956]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to provide for the appointment of Commissions of Inquiry and for vesting such Commissions with certain powers. 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the appointment of Commissions of Inquiry and for vesting such Commissions with certain powers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title, extent and commencement</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the 2[ * * *] Commissions of Inquiry Act, 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of 3[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definitions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Commission” means a Commission of Inquiry appointed or deemed to have been appointed under section 3; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under section 12.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Appointment of Commission</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) The Government may, if it is of opinion that it is necessary so to do, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint a Commission of Inquiry for the purpose of making an inquiry into any definite matter of public importance and performing such functions and within such time as may be specified in the notification, and the Commission so appointed shall make the inquiry and perform the functions accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Commission may consist of one or more members appointed by the Government, and where the Commission consists of more than one member, one of them may be appointed as the President thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Powers of Commission</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The Commission shall have the powers of a civil court, while trying a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, in respect of the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        summoning and enforcing the attendance of any person and examining him on oath;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        requiring the discovery and production of any documents;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        receiving evidence on affidavits;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        issuing commissions for the examination of witnesses or documents.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Additional powers of Commission</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) Where the Government is of opinion that, having regard to the nature of the inquiry to be made and other circumstances of the case, all or any of the provisions of sub-section (2) or sub-section (3) or sub-section (4) or sub-section (5) or sub-section (6) should be made applicable to a Commission, the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct that all or such of the said provisions as may be specified in the notification shall apply to that Commission and on the issue of such a notification, the said provisions shall apply accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Commission shall have power to require any person, subject to any privilege which may be claimed by that person under any law for the time being in force, to furnish information on such points or matters as, in the opinion of the Commission, may be useful for, or relevant to, the subject matter of the inquiry.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The President or any officer, not below the rank of a gazetted officer, specially authorised in this behalf by the President may enter any building or place where the Commission has reason to believe that any books of account or other documents relating to the subject matter of the inquiry may be found, and may seize any such books of account or documents or take extracts or copies therefrom, subject to the provisions of section 102 and section 103 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, in so far as they may be applicable.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Commission shall be deemed to be a civil Court and when any offence as is described in section 175, section 178, section 179, section 180 or section 228 of the 4[ * * *] Penal Code, is committed in the view or presence of the Commission, the Commission may, after recording the facts constituting the offence and the statement of the accused as provided for in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, forward the case to a magistrate having jurisdiction to try the same and the magistrate to whom any such case is forwarded shall proceed to hear the complaint against the accused as if the case had been forwarded to him under section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) Any proceeding before the Commission shall be deemed to be a judicial proceeding within the meaning of sections 193 and 228 of the 5[ * * *] Penal Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) The Commission shall have the powers of a civil court, while trying a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, in respect of requisitioning any public record or copy thereof from any court or office.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Statements made by persons to the Commission</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. No statement made by a person in the course of giving evidence before the Commission shall subject him to, or be used against him in, any civil or criminal proceeding except a prosecution for giving false evidence by such statement:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the statement-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        is made in reply to a question which he is required by the Commission to answer; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        is relevant to the subject matter of inquiry.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Commission to cease to exist when so notified</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. The Government may, if it is of opinion that the continued existence of a Commission is unnecessary, by notification in the official Gazette, declare that the Commission shall cease to exist from such date as may be specified in this behalf in such notification, and thereupon, the Commission shall cease to exist.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Procedure to be followed by the Commission</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. The Commission shall subject to any rules that may be made in this behalf, have power to regulate its own procedure (including the fixing of places and times of its sittings and deciding whether to sit in public or in private) and may act notwithstanding the temporary absence of any member or the existence of a vacancy among its members.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Protection of action taken in good faith</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. No suit or other legal proceedings shall lie against the Government, the Commission or any member thereof, or any person acting under the direction either of the Government or of the Commission in respect of anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done in pursuance of this Act or of any rules or orders made thereunder or in respect of the publication, by or under the authority of the Government or the Commission, of any report, paper or proceedings.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Members, etc, to be public servants</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. Every member of the Commission and every officer appointed or authorised by the Commission to exercise functions under this Act shall be deemed to be a public servant within the meaning of section 21 of the 6[ * * *] Penal Code.        7[</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10A</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8[ 10A. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette and subject to such conditions or restrictions if any, as may be mentioned in the notification, confer upon the Commission the power to order a police investigation into any matter coming before it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In conducting an investigation ordered under sub-section (1) the police shall exercise the powers conferred on the police in respect of a cognizable case by Chapter XIV of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Act to apply to other inquiring authorities in certain cases</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. Where any authority (by whatever name called), other than a Commission appointed under section 3, has been or is set up under any resolution or order of the Government for the purpose of making an inquiry into any definite matter of public importance and the Government is of opinion that all or any of the provisions of this Act should be made applicable to that authority, the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct that the said provisions of this Act shall apply to that authority, and on the issue of such notification, that authority shall be deemed to be a Commission appointed under section 3 for the purpose of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules to carry out the purposes of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. [Repeal of Ordinance XXIV of 1955.- Repealed by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">____________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, the word “Government” was substituted for the words “Central Government” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The word “Bangladesh” was substituted for the word “Pakistan” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 Section 10A was inserted by section 2 of the Pakistan Commissions of Inquiry (Amendment) Ordinance, 1959 (Ordinance No. XXXVIII of 1959)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 Section 10A was inserted by section 2 of the Pakistan Commissions of Inquiry (Amendment) Ordinance, 1959 (Ordinance No. XXXVIII of 1959)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
207	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  THE CONTROL OF DISORDERLY AND DANGEROUS PERSONS (GOONDAS) ACT, 1954 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content">                        						 <p align="center"><strong>THE CONTROL OF DISORDERLY AND DANGEROUS PERSONS (GOONDAS) ACT, 1954</strong></p><p align="center">(EAST BENGAL ACT NO. IV OF 1954)</p><p align="right">[30th July, 1954]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to provide for the better control of riotous and disorderly persons commonly known as goondas residing in or frequenting certain 2[ areas] 3[ * * *].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[ WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for special measures for better control of disorderly persons commonly known as goondas in certain cities and towns and the neighbourhood of those towns and cities and for ancillary matters;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in exercise of the powers so assumed, the Governor is pleased hereby to enact as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title, extent and commencement</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the 5[ * * *] Control of Disorderly and Dangerous Persons (Goondas) Act, 1954.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of 6[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force in such 7[ area or areas], and on such dates, as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definitions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Unless the context otherwise requires, all expressions used in this Act shall have the meanings assigned to them in the 8[ * * *] Penal Code, 1860, or in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Constitution of Tribunal</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9[ 3. The Government may, for the purposes of this Act, by notification in the official Gazette, constitute for such area or areas to which this Act may be applied, a Tribunal (hereinafter called the Tribunal) consisting of the District Magistrate or the Additional District Magistrate.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Powers of Tribunal</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) For the purpose of conducting enquiries under this Act, the Tribunal shall have all the powers of a District Magistrate under the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, for issuing summonses and warrants for the production of witnesses and documents, for the examination of persons complained of and witnesses, and for issuing commissions for the examination of witnesses.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Proceedings before the Tribunal shall be deemed to be judicial proceedings within the meaning of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Tribunal shall keep its records in 10[ Bengali].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Contempt Proceedings</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. The Tribunal shall have the powers of a Court of Record for punishing contempts of its authority provided that the maximum period for which any person may be committed to prison under this provision, shall be three months.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Orders by Tribunal</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. The Tribunal shall not be bound to follow the rules of evidence prescribed under the Evidence Act, 1872, and may inter alia by written order-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        direct that the whole or any part of the enquiry against any person complained of shall be held in camera;(b)       for reasons to be stated in the order, accept evidence on affidavit of witnesses whose presence cannot be secured without such amount of delay or expense as would in the opinion of the Tribunal be unreasonable in the circumstances of the case, or any other ground sufficient in its opinion and connected with any matter arising in the case;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        for reasons to be stated in the order, record the statement of any witness in camera in the absence of the person complained against and his counsel, if the Tribunal is satisfied that the person complained against is deliberately evading appearance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        receive in relation to the person complained of evidence of previous conviction or previous occasions of having been bound over to keep the peace or be of good behaviour;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        receive evidence of general repute in relation to the person complained of;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         direct any Magistrate having jurisdiction in the area to take such steps as may be necessary to protect the life and property of any person who has given or is required to give evidence in an enquiry under this Act;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        grant immunity from prosecution to any witness appearing in any enquiry under this Act, in respect of any matter relevant to the enquiry contained in his evidence; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) direct, with reference to specified portions of the record of the enquiry, that no copies or abstracts shall be made by or furnished to any person including the persons complained of.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Cognizance of cases by Tribunal</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) The Tribunal shall take cognizance of a case only when an information in respect of a specified person is laid before it by a police officer of the area concerned, not below the rank of an Inspector of Police 11[ or Sub-Inspector of Police in charge of Police Station] who has taken part in the investigation of the case. The information shall be signed by the officer concerned and shall briefly set out-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the practices with which the person complained of is charged;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        instances, with details of time and place, of such practices;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        a statement of any relevant general reputation in which the said person is held and any other ground on which the information is based;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        names and other particulars of witnesses who will be produced to support the allegations contained in the information; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        whether the said person is sought to be declared a goonda or a dangerous goonda.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The officer laying the information may, if he thinks fit, enclose any of the above particulars in a sealed cover and request that the same be kept secret and the Tribunal shall order that such particulars shall not be disclosed at any stage of the enquiry, and that when the said particulars fall under clause (d) of sub-section (1) the name of the witness shall not be disclosed until such time as such witness is produced in evidence:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that if the said officer or the person conducting the prosecution before the Tribunal desires that the name of any witness may not be disclosed at all, the Tribunal shall order accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Summoning of the person complained of</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. On receipt of an information under section 7, the Tribunal shall summon the person complained of to appear before it and shall at the same time supply him with a copy of such portion of the information as is not to be kept secret under the provisions of the preceding section:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that when the Tribunal is satisfied that such action is necessary, it may, in the very first instance or at any later stage of the enquiry, instead of issuing a summons or notice issue a warrant, non-bailable or bailable in such sum as may appear to it reasonable, for the arrest of the aforesaid person and his production before the Tribunal and may also issue such warrant if satisfied that the said person is hiding himself to evade service of the summons or if he does not appear in spite of the service of the summons.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Appearance before Tribunal</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) When the person complained of appears before it, the Tribunal may take a bond from him with or without sureties for his appearance during the enquiry or when called upon, as the case may be, and may also having regard to the nature of the information laid against him, require him to furnish a bond, with one or more sureties, in such sum as the Tribunal may think fit, to be of good behaviour until the conclusion of the enquiry, and may direct that he may be detained in custody until such bond is executed, or in default of execution, until the enquiry is concluded.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Tribunal may, for reasons to be recorded, instead of taking a bond for the appearance of the person complained of, order his detention in such custody as may be prescribed by the Government by a general or special order till the conclusion of the enquiry by it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Proceedings before Tribunal</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. The Tribunal shall then proceed to enquire into the truth or otherwise of the information upon which action has been taken, and for that purpose to take such evidence as may appear necessary, following in all cases the procedure prescribed in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 for conducting trials and recording evidence in summary cases, but subject to the other provisions of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>No de novo proceedings</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. It shall not be necessary for the Tribunal to record the evidence of any witness de novo by reason only of a change in its own composition, but the Tribunal may at any time summon and examine any person, who in its opinion, is capable of giving information relevant to any matter under enquiry notwithstanding that such person has already given evidence in such enquiry.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Joint proceedings</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. Where two or more persons are associated together with regard to any matter covered by the allegations contained in the information respectively laid in respect of each, to an extent which in the opinion of the Tribunal justifies such a course, the enquiry into the matter with regard to which they are associated together may be conducted against all or any of them jointly, or against each of them separately, as the Tribunal shall think just.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Declaration of goondas and dangerous goondas</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13.       (1) If the Tribunal is satisfied, as a result of enquiry held under this Act, that the person complained against-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         frequents for immoral purposes houses or localities inhabited by prostitutes; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        frequents resorts of vice such as drinking or gambling dens, or places where opium or other intoxicating drugs are smoked or otherwise consumed; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       generally appears in public while drunk; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iv)       is addicted to smoking opium; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(v)        uses obscene or abusive language in public; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(vi)       makes fraudulent collection in the name of charity;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(vii)      is involved in affray, rowdism or acts of intimidation or violence in any place private or public so as to cause alarm to the people living or frequenting the neighbourhood;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">it shall declare that such person is a goonda and direct that his name be publicly notified in the prescribed manner, and placed on the prescribed list of goondas.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If the Tribunal is satisfied, as a result of enquiry as aforesaid, that any person complained against-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         having previously been declared a goonda has since such declaration acted in any manner specified in the preceding sub-section, or has contravened any prohibitory order published under section 15 made in respect of him by the Tribunal; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) corrupts young persons, by initiating them in the practice of any vice which if established against any person to the satisfaction of the Tribunal would entail his being declared a goonda or a dangerous goonda under this section; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       annoys or molests other persons, particularly women or young persons; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iv)       publishes, distributes, circulates, sells or offers for sale an obscene book or picture or other objects; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(v)        does obscene acts including wilfully exposing his person in public; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(vi)       insults the modesty of women by using foul language or making indecent sounds or gestures, or by exposure of his person or the person of any other individual or of any object or otherwise howsoever; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(vii)      engages in kidnapping or seducing women or young persons or procuring women or young persons for immoral purposes; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(viii)      indulges in unnatural carnal intercourse; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ix)       keeps a drinking or gambling den, or place where opium or other intoxicating drugs are smoked or otherwise consumed, or makes livelihood out of such den or place by acting as a tout or otherwise howsoever, or engages in the illicit manufacture or sale of liquor or opium or other intoxicating drugs; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(x)        behaves riotously in public by entering into affrays, or otherwise howsoever; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xi)       causes fear or alarm to the public or any section or member thereof, by issuing threats verbally or in writing, or by making, publishing or circulating false statements, rumours or reports; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xii)      is a bully, who assaults or threatens persons with the object of causing fear or alarm, or to compel them to act or not to act in a manner in which they are not bound to act, or as the case may be are entitled to act; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xiii) makes livelihood, or extorts money or other property, or seeks any concession or favour from any one, by any form of intimidation; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xiv)     utters counterfeit coins; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xv)      is by habit a smuggler of goods through customs or octroi or other tax barriers, without payment of the requisite duty or tax or in contravention of a lawful order prohibiting the export or import across such barriers; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xvi) is by habit a forger; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xvii) makes a livelihood out of, or otherwise practices whether by himself or in association with other persons, the receiving or disposal of stolen property; or(xviii) makes a livelihood by cheating, fraud, black marketing (that is to say, engaging in transactions involving the transfer, sale or movement of goods in contravention of any lawful order controlling such transfer, sale or movement), acting as an intermediary between bribe givers and corrupt officials or persons in public life, or by any other corrupt or dishonest means;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">it shall declare that such person is a dangerous goonda, and shall direct that his name be publicly notified in the prescribed manner, and be placed on the prescribed list of dangerous goondas.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Special orders against goondas and dangerous goondas</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. While making declaration under section 13 the Tribunal may take such action, as it may deem fit, in one or more of the following ways:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1)        Where the declaration is that the person complained of is a goonda,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        it may, in view of his age and antecedents, and the fact that some person of mature age, who is in a position of authority over him, by virtue of relationship or otherwise, becomes responsible for his good behaviour and executes a bond or other document to the satisfaction of the Tribunal to this effect, release him after due admonition;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        it may require the person complained of to furnish a bond, with one or more sureties, for such period not exceeding three years and in such amount as may be specified, to be of good behaviour:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that where the person complained of is a minor, a bond executed by a surety or sureties only, may be accepted;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        it may direct that the person complained of shall not visit any house or quarter inhabited by prostitutes, or any drinking or gambling den, or any place where opium or other intoxicating drugs are smoked or otherwise consumed or any other specified locality.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        In the case of a person who is declared a dangerous goonda,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        it may direct that his movements shall be restricted to any area specified in the order; or may direct him to report himself at such times and places and in such mode as may be specified in the order, or it may make both the directions; or may direct that he shall be externed from the city or town and neighbouring areas thereof for which it has been constituted;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        it may direct that he shall not visit or go within surroundings, specified in the order or any of the undermentioned places, without the written permission of the officer-in-charge of the police-station within whose jurisdiction, such places are situated, namely,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         schools, colleges, and other institutions where young persons are given education or other training or are housed permanently or temporarily;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        theatres, cinemas, fairs, amusement parks, and other places of public entertainment;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       public halls, restaurants, tea shops, and other places of public resort;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iv)       public or private parks and gardens;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(v)        public or private playing fields and race-courses; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(vi)       the scene of any public meeting or procession or any assemblage of the public, whether in an enclosed place or otherwise, in connection with any public event or festival or other celebration.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Publication of declaration</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. An order under section 13 declaring any person to be a goonda or a dangerous goonda shall be published along with a statement of the order or orders, if any, made in respect of such persons under section 14, in such manner and containing such details as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Bond under Tribunal’s orders</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. (1) Every bond furnished in compliance with an order made by the Tribunal under this Act shall be in the form prescribed by the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, for a bond of the same description:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Tribunal may direct that the sureties offered may be scrutinised by a Magistrate of the first class nominated for the purpose by the District Magistrate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Tribunal may, where a person who has furnished a bond for his appearance makes default, direct, in addition to action under the other provisions of this Act, that a warrant shall be issued for the production of such person, which may be bailable or non-bailable as the Tribunal may direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Where default is made in furnishing sureties, the Tribunal may direct that the person from whom such sureties were demanded shall be committed to prison or if he is already in prison, shall be detained in prison, until the sureties furnished or the period for which the security is demanded expires, or the Tribunal makes an order for the release of the person detained, whether conditional or otherwise.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Any surety may apply to be released from obligation of his bond, and the Tribunal may, after such enquiry as it may deem fit, call upon the person who is bound down to furnish a fresh surety, and thereupon the provisions of sub-sections (1) and (3) shall apply in relation thereto:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the surety seeking release shall not be released from his obligations unless a fresh surety has been accepted in his place or in case no surety is furnished or accepted, he produces the person concerned before the Tribunal.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The provisions of section 514 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, shall apply in respect of the forfeiture of bonds furnished under this Act, as if for the expression ‘Court' the expression ‘Tribunal' wherever applicable for the purposes of this Act, were substituted, and as if from sub-section (1) of the said section, the reference to a Magistrate of the first class were omitted, and as if in sub-section (7) of the said section-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         the reference to section 106 or section 118 or section 562 of that Code were replaced by a reference to clause (1)(b) of section 14 of this Act; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        the reference to a bond executed in lieu of the bond under section 514B of that Code were replaced by a reference to the proviso to clause (1)(b) of section 14 of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) A breach of any order made against any person under clause (1)(c) or clause (2) (a) or clause (2)(b) of section 14, or the commission of any offence which is punishable with imprisonment under any law for the time being in force and which in the opinion of the Tribunal involves or implies moral turpitude, shall amount to a breach of a bond for good behaviour which may have been furnished by him under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Revision of Tribunal’s orders</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. No appeal shall lie from any order made by the Tribunal but in relation to any such order under section 5 or section 13 or section 16, the 12[ High Court Division] may call for the record of the case, and if the Tribunal appear-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        to have exercised a jurisdiction not vested in it by law,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        to have failed to exercise a jurisdiction so vested, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        to have acted in the exercise of its jurisdiction illegally,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the 13[ High Court Division] may make such direction as it may deem sufficient for the rectification of the error or omission and the Tribunal shall conduct itself accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Enhanced punishments in some cases</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. Notwithstanding anything contained in the 14[ * * *] Penal Code, the Whipping Act, 1909, or any other law for the time being in force, when a dangerous goonda is convicted under an Act mentioned in the first column of the Schedule to this Act for an offence punishable under any of the sections of that Act mentioned against it in the second column of the said Schedule, the maximum punishment that may be awarded, on such conviction shall be that appearing in the corresponding entry in the third column thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Procedure where a person absconds or conceals himself</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. If the Tribunal has reason to believe that a person against whom a warrant of arrest has been issued under section 8, has absconded, or is concealing himself, so that the warrant cannot be executed, it may-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        send a report to a Magistrate having jurisdiction in the area where the person complained of ordinarily resides or has his property or is present, and the said Magistrate shall take proceedings under sections 87, 88 and 89 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, in respect of the said person and his property as if the warrant were a warrant issued by the said Magistrate; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        by order notified in the official Gazette direct the said person to appear before it, at such place and within such period as may be specified in the order; and if the said person omits to comply with such direction, he shall, unless he proves that it was not possible for him to comply therewith and that he had at the first possible opportunity within the period sent information to the Tribunal of the reasons which rendered compliance therewith impossible and of his whereabouts, be deemed to have evaded compliance with the order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Photographs, fingerprints, etc</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. Every person, in respect of whom an order has been made under section 13 of this Act, shall, if so directed by the Tribunal present himself before such officer of the Government and at such place and time as may be specified in the order-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         for being photographed;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        for giving his finger impressions or if literate, specimens of his handwriting and signature; and such person shall allow himself to be photographed and shall affix his finger impressions as required or as the case may be supply specimens of his handwriting and signature.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Offences cognizable and non-bailable</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. Notwithstanding anything contained in any other laws for the time being in force, every offence punishable under this Act, shall, within the meaning of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, be cognizable and non-bailable.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Bar of Civil or Criminal Proceedings</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. No proceedings taken or orders passed under this Act, shall be called in question otherwise than as provided hereunder and no civil or criminal proceedings shall be instituted against any person for anything done or intended or purporting to be done under this Act, or against any person for any loss or damage caused to or in respect of any property, as a result of an act done or purporting to be done under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Effect of other law and enactments</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. The provisions of this Act, and any order made or action taken under this Act, shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any enactment, other than this Act, for the time being in force, and in any instrument having effect by virtue of any such enactment other than this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalty for breaches of orders</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. (1) A breach of any order made under clause (1)(c) or clause (2)(a) or clause (2)(b) of section 14 shall be punishable with imprisonment of either description which in the case of a goonda may extend to one year and in the case of dangerous goonda to three years.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A breach of any order made or direction given under this Act not otherwise provided for shall be punishable with imprisonment of either description which may extend to one year or with fine or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Appointment and duties of Probation Officer</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. (1) The Government shall, in each city or town for which a Tribunal has been constituted, appoint an officer of police not lower in rank than a Deputy Superintendent of Police to be a Probation Officer.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall be the duty of the Probation Officer under the general control of the Tribunal-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        to have the superintendence of all goondas and dangerous goondas in the city or town in which he has been appointed with a view to preventing them from evil association and assisting in their rehabilitation as useful citizens;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        to make reports at prescribed times and in the prescribed manner to the Tribunal regarding the general behaviour of each such goonda, and the manner of dealing with him;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to make recommendations, as and when justified by the general behaviour of any such goonda for releasing him from any bond for good behaviour or from any order of prohibition or detention made in respect of him under sub-section (1)(b) or sub-section (1)(c) or sub-section (2)(a) or sub-section (2)(b) of section 14, as the case may be; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        to make recommendations, as and when justified by marked improvement in the general behaviour, manner of life and character of any goonda or dangerous goonda that his name may be removed from any list on which it is carried.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Action on Probation Officer’s report</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">26. On receipt of a periodical report, or as the case may be, a recommendation, from the Probation Officer, the Tribunal may in the case of any goonda or dangerous goonda after such enquiry as it may deem necessary, direct-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        that he be released from any bond for good behaviour furnished by him or on his account and from any order of detention or of prohibition made in respect of him under section 14; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        that his name be removed from the list of goondas or dangerous goondas, as the case may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Secret record</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">27. The record of the proceedings held by the Tribunal or any portion thereof for which the person laying the information or conducting the prosecution before the Tribunal, has claimed privilege before the Tribunal or which he has requested for being kept a secret shall not be available for inspection by any one during the enquiry before the Tribunal or any revision proceedings before the 15[ High Court Division] hearing the revision, or after the disposal of the case, and such records shall after the disposal of the enquiries be kept in such custody as the Government may prescribe.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">28. (1) The Government may make rules, not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act, for carrying out the purposes of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the power conferred by sub-section (1), such rules may provide for-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the lists to be maintained in which the names of goondas or dangerous goondas are to be registered, and the manner of such registration;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the manner in which the names of persons who are declared to be goondas or dangerous goondas shall be publicly notified;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the manner in which an order under clause (a) of sub-section (2) of section 14 operate; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the periods for which and the manner in which Probation Officer shall make reports to the Tribunal regarding the general behaviour of goondas and dangerous goondas.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">______________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, the word “Government” was substituted for the words “Provincial Government” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word “areas” was substituted for the words “cities and towns” by section 2 of the East Bengal Control of Disorderly and Dangerous persons (Goondas) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1970 (East Pakistan Ordinance No. XI of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 The words “area or areas” were substituted for the words “city or town and neighbouring areas thereof” by section 3 of the East Bengal Control of Disorderly and Dangerous persons (Goondas) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1970 (East Pakistan Ordinance No. XI of 1970)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 Section 3 was substituted by section 4 of the East Bengal Control of Disorderly and 208	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE CONTROL OF ENTRY ACT, 1952 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>THE CONTROL OF ENTRY ACT, 1952 </strong></p><p style="text-align: center;">(ACT NO. LV OF 1952)</p><p style="text-align: right;">[14th December, 1952]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to make better provision for controlling the entry of Indian citizens into Bangladesh. 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make better provision for controlling the entry of Indian citizens into Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title, extent and commencement</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the 2[ * * *] 3[ Control of Entry] Act, 1952.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “enter” means enter by water, land or air;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “passport” means a passport issued or renewed by or under the authority of a person duly empowered to issue or renew it and satisfying the conditions prescribed relating to the class of passports to which it belongs;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “visa” means a visa duly endorsed by an authority empowered in this behalf by or under the authority of the Government on a passport valid and in force;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “Indian citizen” means a person who is or is deemed to be a citizen of India under the law for the time being in force in India;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) “Bangladesh citizen” means a person who is or is deemed to be a citizen of Bangladesh under the law for the time being in force in Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        “officer” means an officer or an employee of the Government 5[ * * *].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Control of entry</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[ 3. No Indian citizen shall enter any part of Bangladesh unless he is in possession of a passport with a visa authorising the entry.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Penalty</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Whoever contravenes 7[ the provision of section 3 shall] be punished with imprisonment which may extend to one year, or with a fine which may extend to one thousand Taka, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">False information</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. Any person who for the purpose of obtaining a passport or a visa 8[ * * *] makes a statement which he knows to be untrue or does not believe to be true, or makes use of a statement which he knows to be untrue or has reason to believe to be untrue shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to one year or with a fine which may extend to one thousand Taka or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to arrest</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) Any police officer, customs officer, or other officer empowered in this behalf by a general or special order of the Government 9[ * * *] or under a rule made under this Act, may arrest without a warrant any person whom such officer reasonably suspects of having contravened 10[ the provision] of section 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) An officer making an arrest under this section shall, without unnecessary delay, take the person arrested or cause him to be taken before a competent Magistrate having jurisdiction in the place where the arrest is made, or to the officer-in-charge of a police station within whose jurisdiction the arrest is made; and the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 11[ * * *] shall, so far as may be, apply in respect of such arrested person.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to remove from Bangladesh</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) The Government may order any person who is not a citizen of Bangladesh convicted under section 4 or section 5 to remove himself from Bangladesh within the time specified in the order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If such person refuses or fails so to remove himself within the specified time,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        he shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to one year or with a fine which may extend to one thousand Taka or with both, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        he may be removed from Bangladesh under the order of the Government, who may use all such means as may, in the circumstances, be necessary to effect the removal.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) [Omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to make rules</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules to carry into effect the purposes of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, the rules may provide for,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the different types of visas which may be granted;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the authorisation or appointment of persons by whom visas may be granted, varied, extended and cancelled;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the charges and fees payable for obtaining application forms and visas and the extension of visas;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the conditions and restrictions which may be imposed under this Act on the holder of a passport;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        the exemptions which may be granted, with or without conditions, to any person or class of persons in respect of any provision of this Act or the rules made thereunder;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         the conditions and restrictions which Indian citizens may be required to comply with;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        the alteration or modification of or exemption from any condition or restriction imposed under a visa on the holder of a passport after his entry into Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        the fixing and notification of check-posts and routes; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) the procedure for registering and reporting to the police required under the rules for certain categories of visa holders.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Rules made under this section may provide that any contravention thereof or of any order issued thereunder shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to one thousand Taka, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Delegation of powers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. The Government may by order direct that any power conferred on it under this Act may in such circumstances and under such conditions, if any, as may be specified in the order, be exercised by any officer or authority subordinate to it or specified by it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Protection of persons acting under this Act</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. No prosecution, suit or other legal proceeding shall be commenced against any person in respect of anything done or purporting to be done in exercise of the powers conferred by or under this Act, except with the sanction of the Government 12[ * * *].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. [Repeal of Ordinance X of 1952 and savings.- Omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, unless otherwise provided, the words “Bangladesh”, “Government” and “Taka” were substituted for the words “Pakistan”, “Central Government” and “rupees” respectively by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The words “Control of Entry” were substituted for the brackets and words “(Control of Entry)” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 Clause (d) was omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The words “or of a Provincial Government or of an Acceding State” were omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 Section 3 was substituted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 The words and figure “the provision of section 3 shall” were substituted for the words and commas “any of the provisions of section 3 shall, for every such contravention,” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 The words “or of claiming an exemption under any of the provisions of this Act or of the rules made thereunder” were omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 The words “or of a Provincial Government or of the Government of an Acceding State” were omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10 The words “the provision” were substituted for the words “any of the provisions” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11 The commas and words “, or, when the arrest is made in a State, of the corresponding law for the time being in force in that State,” were omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12 The words “or the Provincial Government or the Government of the State concerned” were omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
209	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE CONTROL OF ESSENTIAL COMMODITIES ACT, 1956 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content">                        						 <p align="center"><strong>THE CONTROL OF ESSENTIAL COMMODITIES ACT, 1956</strong></p><p align="center">(EAST PAKISTAN ACT NO. I OF 1956)</p><p align="right">[22nd September, 1956]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to provide for powers to control the production, treatment, keeping, storage, movement, transport, supply, distribution, disposal, acquisition, use or consumption of, and trade and commerce in, certain commodities. 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for powers to control the production, treatment, keeping, storage, movement, transport, supply, distribution, disposal, acquisition, use or consumption of, and trade and commerce in, certain commodities within 2[ Bangladesh];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title, extent and commencement</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the 3[ * * *] Control of Essential Commodities Act, 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of 4[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definitions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “essential commodity” means any of the following classes of commodities:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         foodstuffs;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        cotton and woollen textiles;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       paper including paper-board, pulp-board, wall-board, fibre board, straw board, box-board, cellulose wadding, cellulose films and other similar materials which are manufactured wholly or mainly either from vegetable fibres or a pulp thereof or both from such fibres and such pulp, but does not include any of these materials;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iv)       mechanically propelled vehicles, their spare parts and tyres and tubes for the same;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(v)        coal;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(vi)       iron and steel;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(vii)      mica;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(viii) drugs and medicines, including those administered by injection;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ix)       chemicals including gases;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(x)        electrical and radio goods and appliances, including wires and cables;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xi)       medical and surgical instruments and appliances;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xii)      glass and glassware including scientific and laboratory equipment;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xiii)      artificial silk yarn;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xiv)     cycles, their spare parts, and tyres and tubes for the same;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xv)      matches;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xvi)     timber;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xvii)     sanitary and water supply fittings;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xviii) infant and patient foods and allied articles;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xix)     cement;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xx)      cigarettes;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xxi)     fertilisers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xxii)     tallow;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xxiii) torch cells;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(xxiv)    such other classes of commodities as may be declared by the Government by notification in the official Gazette to be essential commodities for the purposes of this Act;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “foodstuffs” shall include edible oilseeds and oils;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “notified order” means an order notified in the official Gazette; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “paper” shall include newsprint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Powers to control production, supply, distribution, etc, of essential commodities</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) The Government, so far as it appears to it to be necessary or expedient for maintaining, or increasing supplies of any essential commodity or for securing its equitable distribution and availability at fair prices, may by notified order provide for regulating, or prohibiting the production, treatment, keeping, storage, movement, transport, supply, distribution, disposal, acquisition, use or consumption thereof and trade and commerce therein.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the powers conferred by sub-section (1), an order made thereunder may provide-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        for regulating by licences, permits or otherwise the production or manufacture of any essential commodity;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        for controlling the prices at which any essential commodity may be bought or sold;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        for regulating by licences, permits or otherwise the storage, transport, distribution, disposal, acquisition, use or consumption of any essential commodity;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        for prohibiting the withholding from sale of any essential commodity kept for sale;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        for requiring any person holding stock of an essential commodity to sell the whole or a specified part of the stock at such prices and to such persons or class of persons or in such circumstances, as may be specified in the order;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         for regulating or prohibiting any class of commercial or financial transactions relating to foodstuffs or cotton textiles which, in the opinion of the authority making the order are, or if unregulated are likely to be, detrimental to public interest;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        for requiring persons engaged in the production, supply or distribution of, trade or commerce in, any essential commodity to maintain and produce for inspection such books, accounts and records relating to their business and to furnish such information relating thereto, as may be specified in the order;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        for any incidental and supplementary matters, including in particular the entering, and search of premises, vehicles, vessels and aircraft, the seizure by a person authorised to make such search of any articles in respect of which such person has reason to believe that a contravention of the order has been, is being, or is about to be committed, or any records connected therewith, the grant or issue of licences, permits or other documents and the charging of fees therefore and for collecting any information or statistics with a view to regulating or prohibiting any of the aforesaid matters.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) An order made under sub-section (1) may confer powers and impose duties upon the Government, or officers and authorities of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Government, so far as it appears to it to be necessary for maintaining or increasing the production and supply of an essential commodity, may by order authorise any person (hereinafter referred to as an authorised controller) to exercise, with respect to the whole or any part of any such undertaking engaged in the production and supply of the commodity as may be specified in the order, such functions of control, as may be provided by the order; and so long as an order made under this sub-section is in force with respect to any undertaking or part thereof-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the authorised controller shall exercise his functions in accordance with any instruction given to him by the Government, so however, that he shall not have any power to give any direction inconsistent with the provisions of any Act or other instrument determining the functions of the undertakers except in so far as may be specifically provided by the order; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the undertaking or part shall be carried on, in accordance with any directions given by the authorised controller in accordance with the provisions of the order, and any person having any functions of management in relation to the undertaking or part shall comply with any such directions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Delegation of powers</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4.
