227	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE JUNIOR CADET CORPS ACT, 1953 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE JUNIOR CADET CORPS ACT, 1953</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. XXXVI OF 1953)</p><p align="right">[5th November, 1953]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the constitution and maintenance of a Junior Cadet Corps for Bangladesh and for its administration; 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title, extent and commencement </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the 2[ * * *] Junior Cadet Corps Act, 1953.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It applies to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “cadet” means a school boy who is deemed to be enrolled as a cadet under sub-section (1) of section 5;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3[ (b) “Chief of Army Staff” means the Chief of Army Staff of the Bangladesh Army;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Constitution of Junior Cadet Corps</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. There 4[ may be raised] and maintained in the manner hereinafter provided a force, which shall be designated the Junior Cadet Corps, and shall consist of units constituted under section 4.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Constitution and organisation of units</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) Subject to the control of the Government, the Chief of Army Staff may, by order in writing, direct the constitution and maintenance for any boys' school in Bangladesh of two separate companies of the Junior Cadet Corps, each company to consist of the boys of one of each of the two final classes of the school, and may direct the disbandment of the companies so constituted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The companies constituted under sub-section (1) from schools located in the same revenue district shall jointly constitute a battalion to be designated after the name of that district.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Certain students to be deemed to be enrolled</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) On the constitution of a company under sub-section (1) of section 4, every student of the class concerned who,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         is above thirteen years of age, at the commencement of the academic year, or by the first day of April of that year, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        is certified on examination by an officer of the Bangladesh Army Medical Corps to be physically fit to undergo the prescribed military training, shall be deemed to have been enrolled as a cadet in that company.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A student who is deemed to be enrolled as a cadet in a company under sub-section (1) shall not cease to belong to that company, until he passes out of or otherwise leaves, the class for which the company was constituted, or is duly certified by an officer of the Bangladesh Army Medical Corps to have become physically unfit to undergo further military training.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Officers of the Junior Cadet Corps</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) The Government, on the recommendation of the Headmaster of the school for which units of the Junior Cadet Corps have been constituted under sub-section (1) of section 4, supported by the 5[ Director General of Public Instruction] and the officer commanding the local military formation being not below the rank of brigadier, may appoint any member of the staff of that school, who is not less than twenty-three and not more than thirty-five years of age, as an officer of the corps.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[ (2) A person appointed officer under sub-section (1) shall be granted a commission in accordance with the provision of Article 61 of the Constitution of the People's Republic of Bangladesh.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Officers to be attached to regular units for training</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. An officer of the Junior Cadet Corps shall be liable, under the orders of the officer commanding the local military formation being not below the rank of brigadier, to be attached to a unit of the regular army for undergoing the military training prescribed for his class.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Officers to be subject to military law</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. An officer of the Junior Cadet Corps shall, when undergoing military training under section 7, be subject to the 7[ * * *] 8[ * * *] Army Act, 1952, in such manner and to such extent as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Allowance of officers</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. An officer of the Junior Cadet Corps may be paid such allowance 9[ as may be determined by the Government]:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that an officer, who is attached to a regular unit for training under section 7, shall receive such additional allowances as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Termination of officer’s commissions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) The Government may withdraw the commission of an officer at any time and for any cause whatever.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) An officer of the Junior Cadet Corps shall cease to hold his commission,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         on ceasing to be a member of the staff of the school from which he received his commission:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that an officer who is immediately re-employed in another school for which companies of the Junior Cadet Corps have been constituted under sub-section (1) of section 4 may, on the recommendation of the Headmaster of that school, be allowed by the Chief of Army Staff to retain his commission;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        on attaining the age of forty-five years.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Military training of cadets</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. A cadet shall be liable to undergo the prescribed military training.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Discipline of cadets</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. (1) The Headmaster of each school shall be Honorary commanding officer of the companies constituted for his school under sub-section (1) of section 4 and the primary responsibility for enforcing discipline in those companies shall rest on him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) With the approval of the Chief of Army Staff the Headmaster of each school may frame rules for the punishment of cadets who wilfully and without reasonable cause absent themselves from parades held for imparting the prescribed military training or who are otherwise guilty of conduct to the prejudice of good order and discipline in the Junior Cadet Corps.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) In addition to any other punishment, which the Headmaster may specify therein, the rules made under sub-section (2) shall provide for the subjection of the offender to extra drill for twenty minutes.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Members of junior cadet corps not to be liable to perform service</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. Officers and cadets of the Junior Cadet Crops shall not be liable to perform military service of any kind whatever.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. The Chief of Army Staff may, with the approval of the Government, make rules to provide for any matter which may be prescribed under this Act and to carry out the purposes of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_________________________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, the words “Bangladesh”, “Government” and “Chief of Army Staff” were substituted for the words “Pakistan”, “Central Government” and “Commander-in-Chief” respectively by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Bangladesh Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 Clause (b) was substituted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The words “may be raised” were substituted for the words “shall be raised” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973) as amended by the Bangladesh Laws (Revision and Declaration) (Second Amendment) Act, 2000 (Act No. XL of 2000)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The words “Director General of Public Instruction” were substituted for the words “Director of Public Instruction of the Province concerned” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 Sub-section (2) was substituted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 The words, comma and figure “Indian Army Act, 1911 or” were omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by section 4 of the Defence Services Laws Amendment Ordinance, 1978 (Ordinance No. XVIII of 1978)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 The words “as may be determined by the Government ” were substituted for the words “by the Provincial Government concerned as may have been agreed upon between the Central Government and the Provincial Government” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
228	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">   THE LAW OF EVIDENCE AMENDMENT ACT, 1956 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content">                        						 <p align="center"><strong>THE LAW OF EVIDENCE AMENDMENT ACT, 1956</strong></p><p align="center">(EAST PAKISTAN ACT NO. XVIII OF 1956)</p><p align="right">[27th December, 1956]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to supplement the Law of Evidence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS doubts exist as to the admissibility of the certified copies of the copies of common records;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">AND WHEREAS it is necessary to remove such doubts;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title, extent and commencement</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the Law of Evidence Amendment Act, 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of 1[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall be deemed to have come into force on the 15th day of August, 1947.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Copies of common records to be public documents</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4)        Notwithstanding anything contained in the Evidence Act, 1872, copies of common records of the divided districts of Bengal and Assam in the custody of a public officer, the originals whereof are either in West Bengal or Assam, shall be deemed to be public document within the meaning of clause (1) of section 74 of the Evidence Act, 1872 and other provisions of the said Act shall apply accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Explanation.- ‘Common records' mean and include documents of public nature in the custody of a public officer immediately before the 15th day of August, 1947, relating to a district or part of a district, which has fallen partly in 2[ the then East Pakistan (now Bangladesh)] and partly in India as a result of the award of the Boundary Commission appointed under section 3 of the Indian Independence Act, 1947.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">______________________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The word “Bangladesh” was substituted for the words “East Pakistan” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words and brackets “the then East Pakistan (now Bangladesh)” were substituted for the word “Pakistan” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
229	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE MILITARY STORES (UNLAWFUL POSSESSION) ORDINANCE, 1943 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>THE MILITARY STORES (UNLAWFUL POSSESSION) ORDINANCE, 1943 </strong></p><p style="text-align: center;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXXIII OF 1943)</p><p style="text-align: right;">[11th October, 1943]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to make special provision for the punishment of the offence of unlawful possession of military stores.        1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS an emergency has arisen which renders it necessary to make special provision for the punishment of the offence of unlawful possession of military stores;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in exercise of the powers conferred by section 72 of the Government of India Act, as set out in the Ninth Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, the Governor General is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title, extent and commencement</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Military Stores (Unlawful Possession) Ordinance, 1943.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Definition </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance “military stores” includes any article intended for use in the equipment of or for supply to the naval, military or air forces of Bangladesh or of any foreign Power allied with Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Unlawful possession of military stores</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Whoever is found or is proved to have been in possession of any article of military stores shall, if the Court sees reasonable grounds for believing such article to be or to have been the property of Government or of a foreign Power allied with Bangladesh, as the case may be, unless he proves that the article came into his possession lawfully, be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years or with fine or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">__________________________________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Ordinance, the word “Bangladesh” was substituted for the word “Pakistan” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
230	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE NATIONAL GUARD ACT, 1950 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content">                        						 <p align="center"><strong>THE NATIONAL GUARD ACT, 1950</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. LXIII OF 1950)</p><p align="right">[23rd October, 1950]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to provide for the constitution and discipline of a National Guard for Bangladesh. 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is necessary to provide for the constitution and discipline of a National Guard for Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title, extent and commencement </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the National Guard Act, 1950.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh and applies to all persons enrolled in the Bangladesh National Guard wherever they may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “district” means a revenue district 2[ * * *];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “enrolled” means enrolled in the Bangladesh National Guard under this Act;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “non-commissioned officer” means a person holding a non-commissioned rank in the Bangladesh National Guard, and includes an acting non-commissioned officer;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “officer” means an officer of either of the two classes specified in section 5; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Constitution of the Bangladesh National Guard</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. There 3[ may be raised] and maintained in the manner hereinafter provided a force to be designated the Bangladesh National Guard.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Constitution and disbandment of units</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4[ 4. The Chief of Army Staff may, subject to the control of the Government, constitute for any district one or more units of the Bangladesh National Guard to be recruited from persons residing in such district and may disband or reconstitute any unit so constituted:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that where, in his opinion, it is not for any reason practicable to recruit a unit from the district for which it has been constituted, he may, by order in writing, authorise its recruitment from persons residing in any other district.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Personnel of the Bangladesh National Guard</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) There shall be the following classes of officers in the Bangladesh National Guard, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         Senior officers holding commissions in the Bangladesh National Guard granted by the President with designation of rank corresponding to those of officers of the Bangladesh Army, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        junior officers holding commissions in the Bangladesh National Guard granted by the President with designation of rank corresponding to those of junior commissioned officers of the Bangladesh Army.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) An officer shall be deemed to be enrolled in the Bangladesh National Guard for so long as he holds a commission therein.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Conditions of enrolment</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) 5[ Any citizen of Bangladesh] may offer himself for enrolment in the Bangladesh National Guard and any such person who satisfies the prescribed conditions may be enrolled for the prescribed period and in the prescribed manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[ (2) Any person residing in a district may apply to be enrolled for service in any unit constituted for that district.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Where, in pursuance of the proviso to section 4, the 7[ Chief of Army Staff of Bangladesh Army] authorises the recruitment of a unit from persons belonging to a district other than that for which the unit was constituted, an applicant for enrolment may, notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (2), apply to be enrolled in any unit so recruited.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Appointment to a unit</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8[ 7. Every person enrolled and residing in a district shall, without unnecessary delay, be appointed to a unit constituted under section 4 for the district or, if he applied for enrolment for the district, in which he resides, to such other unit.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Transfer and attachment</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) Any person appointed to a unit constituted under section 4 may be transferred, whether on disbandment of the unit or, otherwise, to another unit of the Bangladesh National Guard in such manner as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall be deemed to authorise the transfer without his own consent of any person enrolled any unit other than the unit to which he was appointed under section 7.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Any person enrolled may be attached at his own request to any unit of the Bangladesh National Guard.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Change of residence</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) Any person enrolled who changes his place of residence and thereby leaves the 10[ * * *] district, if the said unit is constituted for that district shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        if he does not intend to return to 11[ that district] inform the prescribed authority of his new place of residence; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) if, having intended to return, he does not return within a period of three months, inform the prescribed authority as aforesaid immediately on the expiry of that period.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The prescribed authority on being informed of a change of address under sub-section (1) may, subject to the provisions of section 8, transfer the aforesaid person from the unit in which he is serving to another unit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Discharge</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) Every person enrolled shall be entitled to receive his discharge from the Bangladesh National Guard on the expiration of the period for which he was enrolled and may, before the expiration of that period, be discharged from the force by such authority and subject to such conditions as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no person enrolled who is for the time being engaged in military service shall be entitled to receive his discharge before the termination of such service.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every person enrolled shall on becoming entitled to his discharge be discharged with all convenient speed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Liability to serve and perform military service</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) Every person enrolled shall, subject to such conditions as may be prescribed, be bound to serve in any unit, of the Bangladesh National Guard to which he has been appointed or transferred or is for the time being attached, and shall be subject to all rules and regulations that may be made under this Act relating to such unit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every person enrolled shall be liable to perform military service-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) when called out with any portion of the Bangladesh National Guard by an order of the senior officer of the Bangladesh Army present, either to act in support of the civil power or to provide guards which, in the opinion of such officer, are essential; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) when the unit to which he belongs has been embodied to support or supplement the Bangladesh Army in the event of an emergency by an order directing such embodiment issued by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) No person enrolled shall be required to perform military service beyond the limits of Bangladesh save under a general or special order of the Government 12[ * * *].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Application of the Indian Army Act, 1911</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. (1) Every officer of the Bangladesh National Guard when doing duty as such officer shall be subject to the provisions of 13[ * * *] the 14[ * * *] Army Act, 1952, and the rules and regulations made thereunder, in the same manner and to the same extent as if such officer held the same rank in the Bangladesh Army as he holds for the time being in the Bangladesh National Guard but subject to the terms of his commission and to any order of the President made in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every non-commissioned officer and man of the Bangladesh National Guard-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) when called out or embodied for military service under section 11, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) when embodied for, or otherwise undergoing military training in the prescribed manner, shall be subject to 15[ * * *] the 16[ * * *] Army Act, 1952, and the rules and regulations made thereunder, and the said Act, rules and regulations shall apply to him, subject to any order of the President made in this behalf as if he held the same rank in the Bangladesh Army as he holds for the time being in the Bangladesh National Guard:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the said Act, rules and regulations shall, in their application to such non commissioned officers and men when embodied for or otherwise undergoing military training, be modified to such extent and in such manner as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) When any offence punishable under 17[ * * *] the 18[ * * *] Army Act, 1952, has been committed by any person while subject to that Act under the provisions of this section such person may, notwithstanding that he may have ceased to be so subject, be taken into and kept in military custody and tried and punished for such offence as aforesaid in like manner as if he had not ceased to be so subject.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Summary trial and punishment</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. In addition to, or in substitution for, any punishment to which he may be liable under 19[ * * *] the 20[ * * *] Army Act, 1952, any person enrolled other than an officer may be punished by a court of competent criminal jurisdiction, or summarily by order of the prescribed authority, for any offence under that Act or for the contravention of any provision of this Act or of any rule made thereunder, with fine which may be extend to one hundred 21[ taka] to be recovered in such manner and by such authority as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no fine shall be summarily inflicted by an order of the prescribed authority in any case in which the accused claims to be tried by a criminal court:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided further, that no court inferior to that of a magistrate of the first class shall try any offence, made punishable by or under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Presumption as to certain documents</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. When any person enrolled, other than an officer, is required by or in pursuance of any rule or order made under this Act to attend at any place, a certificate purporting to be signed by the prescribed officer stating that the person so required to attend has failed to attend in accordance with such requirement shall, without proof of the signature or appointment of such officer be evidence of the matter stated therein.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Persons subject to the Act to be deemed part of the Bangladesh Army</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. For the purposes of sections 128, 130 and 131 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, all officers, non-commissioned officers and men of the Bangladesh National Guard who have been appointed to a unit shall be deemed to be officers, non-commissioned officers and soldiers respectively of the Bangladesh Army.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Exemption from local taxation</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. No person shall be liable to pay any municipal or other tax in respect of any horse, bicycle, motor bicycle, motor car or other conveyance which he is required or authorised by a general or special order of the 22[ Chief of Army Staff of Bangladesh Army] to maintain in his capacity as a person enrolled in or as a person otherwise connected with the Bangladesh National Guard.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. (1) The Government may by notification in the official Gazette make such rules as appear to it to be necessary for carrying into effect the provisions of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular, and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) prescribe the conditions subject to which, the period for which and the manner in which, persons may be enrolled under section 6;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) prescribe the manner in which a person enrolled may be transferred under section 8;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) prescribe the authorities by whom and the conditions subject to which persons enrolled may be discharged under section 10;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) prescribe the authorities by which offences under this Act may be punished and the manner in which fine inflicted may be recovered;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) prescribe the military training, compulsory or voluntary, for any person or class of persons enrolled and to provide for the embodiment of any unit for that purpose;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         prescribe the extent to which and the manner in which the provisions of 23[ * * *] the 24[ * * *] Army Act, 1952, shall be modified in their application to non- commissioned officers and men of the Bangladesh National Guard when embodied for or otherwise undergoing military training;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        provide for and regulate the remuneration, allowances, gratuities or compensation (if any) to be paid to any person or class of persons enrolled or to their dependents;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) prescribe the officers by whom certificates may be signed under section 14;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) provide for the medical examination of persons offering themselves for enrolment under section 5; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) provide for any other matter which under this Act is to be or may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make regulations</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. (1) The 25[ Chief of Army Staff of Bangladesh Army], may make regulations not inconsistent with this Act and the rules made thereunder providing generally for all details connected with the organisation and personnel of the Bangladesh National Guard and for the duties, military training, clothing, equipment, allowance and leave of persons enrolled.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such regulations may specify the courses of training or instruction to be followed by any person or class of persons enrolled.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19.
