233	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE OILSEEDS COMMITTEE ACT, 1946 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content">                        						 <p align="center"><strong>THE OILSEEDS COMMITTEE ACT, 1946</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO.IX OF 1946)</p><p align="right">[18th April, 1946]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to provide for financing a Committee for the improvement and development of the cultivation and marketing of oilseeds and of the production, manufacture and marketing of oilseed products.  1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for financing a Committee for the improvement and development of the cultivation and marketing of oilseeds and of the production, manufacture and marketing of oilseed products;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title and extent</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the Oilseeds Committee Act, 1946.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definitions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “Collector” means the officer appointed by the Government to perform in any specified area the duties of a Collector under the provisions of this Act and the rules made thereunder, and includes any officer subordinate to that officer whom he may by order in writing authorise to perform his duties under those provisions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “the Committee” means the Bangladesh Food and Agriculture Committee set up under sub section (1) of section 5A of the Agricultural Produce Cess Act, 1940, or any body which replaces the said Committee under sub section (2) of that section;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “grower” means an agriculturist who grows oilseeds, with or without the aid of hired labour;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “mill” means any place in which oilseeds are crushed with the aid of power, which is a factory as defined in section 2 of the 2[ Factories Act, 1965];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) “oilseeds” does not include coconuts;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Imposition of oilseeds cess</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) There shall be levied and collected on and after the date of the commencement of this Act as cesses for the purposes of this Act,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        on all oils extracted from oilseeds crushed in any mill in Bangladesh, whether the oilseeds are produced in or imported from outside Bangladesh, a duty of excise at the rate of 3[ six poisha] per maund, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        on all oilseeds exported out of Bangladesh to a destination outside Bangladesh, a duty of customs at the rate of 4[ twelve poisha] per maund:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Government may from time to time fix by notification in the official Gazette a different rate at which the duty of excise or duty of customs shall be levied and collected:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided further that no such duty of customs shall be levied on any oilseeds exported under a contract for export entered into before the aforesaid date.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) On the last day of each month, or as soon thereafter as may be convenient, the proceeds of the duties recovered during that month shall, after deduction of the expenses, if any, of collection and recovery, be paid to the Committee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The proceeds of the duties recovered since the fifteenth day of August 1947 after deduction of the expenses, if any, of collection and recovery shall be paid to the Committee forthwith.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. [Constitution of Indian Oilseeds Committee.- Omitted by section 7 of the Oilseeds Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XIX of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. [Incorporation of the Committee.- Omitted by section 7 of the Oilseeds Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XIX of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. [Vacancies.- Omitted by section 7 of the Oilseeds Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XIX of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. [President of Committee, Secretary, Sub committees and staff.- Omitted by section 7 of the Oilseeds Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XIX of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. [Appointment of officers.- Omitted by section 7 of the Oilseeds Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XIX of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Application of fund</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) The Committee shall take such measures as it may consider necessary or expedient for the improvement and development of the cultivation and marketing of oilseeds and of the production, utilisation and marketing of oilseed products.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, the Committee may defray expenditure involved in¬-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) undertaking, assisting or encouraging agricultural, industrial, technological and economic research, in¬cluding research into the food value of oilseeds and oilseed products;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        supplying technical advice to growers and millers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        encouraging the adoption of improved methods of cultivation and storage of oilseeds;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        producing, testing and distributing improved varieties of oilseeds or assisting such work;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        assisting in the control of insect and other pests and diseases of oilseeds both in the field and in storage;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) promoting the improvement of the marketing of oilseeds and their products including the setting up and adoption of grade standards for oilseeds and their products;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        collecting statistics from growers, dealers and millers on all relevant matters and promoting improvement in the forecasting of oilseed crops and the preparation of all relevant statistics relating to oilseeds and oilseed products;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        maintaining, and assisting in the maintenance of, such institutes, farms and stations as it may consider necessary;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         advising and providing assistance on all matters connected with the improvement of the cultivation of oilseeds (including advising on the best and most suitable varieties of oilseeds to be cultivated) and the improvement of the industries using oilseeds or their products;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         promoting and encouraging the co operative movement in the oilseeds industry;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        adopting such measures as may be practicable for assuring remunerative returns to growers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)         organising the establishment of growers', millers' and consumers' associations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m)       aiding and encouraging the establishment of exhibitions for demonstrating the uses of oilseeds and oilseed products;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n)        adopting any other measures or performing any other duties which it may be required by the Government to adopt or perform or which the Committee may itself think necessary or advisable in order to carry out the purposes of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Delivery of monthly returns</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) The owner of every mill shall furnish to the Collector, on or before the 7th day of each month, a return stating the total amount of oils extracted in the mill during the preceding month, together with such further information in regard thereto as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no return shall be required in regard to oils extracted before the commencement of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every such return shall be made in such form and shall be verified in such manner as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Collection of duty of excise</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) On receiving any return made under section 10, the Collector shall assess the amount of the duty of excise payable under section 3 in respect of the period to which the return relates, and if the amount has not already been paid, shall cause a notice to be served upon the owner of the mill requiring him to make payment of the amount assessed within thirty days of the service of the notice.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If the owner of any mill fails to furnish in due time the return referred to in sub section (1) of section 10 or furnishes a return which the Collector has reason to believe is incorrect, or defective, the Collector shall assess the amount, if any, payable by him in such manner as may be prescribed, and the provisions of sub section (1) shall thereupon apply as if such assessment had been made on the basis of a return furnished by the owner:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, in the case of a return which he has reason to believe is incorrect or defective, the Collector shall not assess the duty of excise at an amount higher than that at which it is assessable on the basis of the return without giving to the owner a reasonable opportunity of proving the correctness and completeness of the return.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A notice under sub section (1) may be served on the owner of a mill either by post or by delivering it or tendering it to the owner or his agent at the mill.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Finality of assessment and recovery of unpaid duty of excise</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. (1) Any owner of a mill who is aggrieved by an assessment made under section 11 may, within three months of service of the notice referred to in sub section (1) of that section, apply to the District Judge, for the cancellation or modification of the assessment and, on such application, the said Judge may cancel or modify the assessment and order the refund to such owner of the whole or part, as the case may be, of any amount paid thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The decision under sub section (1) of the District Judge shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Any sum recoverable under section 11 may be recovered as an arrear of land revenue.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to inspect mills and take copies of records and accounts</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) The Collector or any officer empowered by general or special order of the Government in this behalf shall have free access at all reasonable times during working hours to any mill or to any part of any mill.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Collector or any such officer may, at any time during working hours, with or without notice to the owner, examine the purchase, sale and stock records and accounts of any mill and take copies of or extracts from all or any of the said records or accounts for the purpose of testing the accuracy of any return or of informing himself as to the particulars regarding which information is required for the purposes of this Act or any rules made thereunder:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing in this section shall be deemed to authorise the examination of any description or formulae of any trade process.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Information acquired to be confidential</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) All such copies and extracts and all information acquired by a Collector or any other officer from an inspection of any mill or warehouse or from any return submitted under this Act shall be treated as confidential.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If the Collector or any such officer discloses to any person other than a superior officer any such information as aforesaid without the previous sanction of the Government, he shall be punishable with imprisonment which may extend to six months and shall also be liable to fine:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to the disclosure of any such information for the purposes of a prosecution in respect of the making of a false return under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. [Keeping and auditing of accounts.- Omitted by section 10 of the Oilseeds Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XIX of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. [Dissolution of Committee.- Omitted by section 10 of the Oilseeds Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XIX of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power of the Government to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. (1) The Government may, after previous publication, make rules for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) [Omitted by section 11 of the Oilseeds Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XIX of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalty for contravention of rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5[ 17A. Rules made under section 17 may provide that a breach of any of them shall be punishable with fine not exceeding one thousand 6[ Taka].]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. [Power of the Committee to make regulations.- Omitted by section 12 of the Oilseeds Committee (Amendment) Act, 1950 (Act No. XIX of 1950).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Publication of rules and regulations</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. All rules made under section 17 shall be published in the official Gazette.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_________________________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, unless otherwise provided, the words “Bangladesh” and “Government” were substituted for the word “Pakistan” and “Central Government” respectively by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words, comma and figure “Factories Act, 1965” were substituted for the words, comma and figure “Factories Act, 1934” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The words “six poisha” were substituted for the words “ one anna” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The words “twelve poisha” were substituted for the words “ two annas” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 Section 17A was inserted by section 3 of the Coconut and Oilseeds Committees Acts (Amendment) Ordinance, 1962 (Ordinance No. XXV of 1962)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 The word “Taka” was substituted for the word “rupees” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
234	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE ORPHANAGES AND WIDOWS’ HOMES ACT, 1944 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE ORPHANAGES AND WIDOWS’ HOMES ACT, 1944</strong></p><p align="center">(BENGAL ACT NO. III OF 1944)</p><p align="right">[29th June, 1944]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to provide for the better control and supervision of orphanages, widows’ homes and marriage bureaux, in Bangladesh.      1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the better control and supervision of orphanages, widows’ homes and marriage bureaux, in Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title, extent and commencement </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the 2[ * * *] Orphanages and Widows' Homes Act, 1944.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force in such areas on such dates as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        “marriage bureau” means an institution, by whatever name it may be called, which negotiates the marriages of persons and includes a place where females of any age are kept or intended to be kept by such institution for the said purpose;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3)        “orphan” means a boy or girl under eighteen years of age who has lost his or her father or has been abandoned by his or her parents or guardians;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4)        “orphanage” means an institution, by whatever name it may be called, where orphans are kept or intended to be kept;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5)        “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Act;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6)        “widow” includes a woman abandoned by her husband;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(7)        “widows' home” means an institution, by whatever name it may be called, where widows or females of any age are kept or intended to be kept.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Act not to apply to certain institutions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Nothing in this Act shall apply to¬-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        a reformatory school, an industrial school or an auxiliary home established or certified by the Government under the 4[ * * *] Children Act, 1922;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        any institution recognised as a place of suitable custody under sub section (1) of section 28 of the 5[ * * *] Children Act, 1922, or under any rule made under clause (b) of sub section (2) of section 27 of the 6[ * * *] Suppression of Immoral Traffic Act, 1933; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        any orphanage or widows' home established and maintained by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Prohibition to open or to carry on an orphanage, a widows’ home or a marriage bureau without a licence</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. No person shall without, or otherwise than in conformity with the conditions of, a licence granted under this Act in the prescribed form open or carry on an orphanage, a widows' home or a marriage bureau:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that a person carrying on any such institution at the commencement of this Act shall be allowed a period of six months from such commencement to obtain such licence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Licence to open or to carry on an orphanage, a widows’ home or a marriage bureau</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) Subject to the provisions of sub section (2) the District Magistrate may, on receipt of an application in the prescribed form containing the prescribed particulars, grant to any person a licence for the opening and carrying on or the carrying on of an orphanage, a widows' home or a marriage bureau (hereinafter referred to as the said institution) on such conditions as may be prescribed in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The District Magistrate shall refuse to grant a licence under sub section (1) unless he is satisfied</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        that for the control and supervision of the said institution a society has, subject to such rules as may be made in this behalf by the Government, been formed and registered under the Societies Registration Act, 1860, the provisions of which shall, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in that Act, apply to every such institution as if such institution is a charitable society;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        that the members of the society are respectable persons of the locality where the said institution is or is to be located;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        that the said institution is or is to be located in a healthy locality and the accommodation therein is sufficient for the purpose for which it is to be opened or is being carried on.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Suspension or cancellation of licence</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. A licence granted under section 5 may be suspended or cancelled by the authority which granted it-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        if there is any contravention of any of the provisions of this Act or any breach of the conditions subject to which the licence was granted; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        if the institution in respect of which the licence was granted has ceased to fulfil the conditions specified in clauses (a) to (c) of sub section (2) of section 5.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Inspection of the institution</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. The District Magistrate or any Magistrate authorised in writing in this behalf by the District Magistrate or any person not in the Government service when authorised in writing in this behalf by the District Magistrate may enter and inspect any orphanage, widows' home or marriage bureau at any time by day or night and the society having control of such institution and the persons in charge thereof shall not refuse such entry or inspection.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalty</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. Whoever acts in contravention of any of the provisions of this Act shall on conviction be punished with fine which may extend to five hundred Taka, and in the case where the contravention is a continuing one with further fine which may extend to fifty Taka for every day after the first during which such contravention continues subsequent to such conviction.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Prosecution</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. No prosecution under this Act shall be instituted except with the previous sanction of the District Magistrate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Jurisdiction</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. No Court inferior to that of a Magistrate of the first class shall try an offence punishable under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) The Government may subject to the condition of previous publication make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the genera¬lity of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for the following matters, namely:¬-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the form of licence to be granted under this Act;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the form of application for licence under sub section (1) of section 5 and the particulars to be contained in such application;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the conditions subject to which licences may be granted; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the formation of a society for the control and supervision of an orphanage, a widows' home or a marriage bureau under clause (a) of sub section (2) of section 5.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">________________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, the words “Bangladesh”, “Government” and “Taka” were substituted for the words “East Pakistan”, “Provincial Government” and “rupees” respectively by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word “Bengal” was omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 Clause (1) was omitted by section 2 and the First Schedule of the East Pakistan Repealing and Amending Ordinance, 1960 (East Pakistan Ordinance No. XXVIII of 1960)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The word “Bengal” was omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The word “Bengal” was omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 The word “Bengal” was omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
235	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE PASSPORT (OFFENCES) ACT, 1952 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>THE PASSPORT (OFFENCES) ACT, 1952 </strong></p><p style="text-align: center;">(ACT NO. LVI OF 1952)</p><p style="text-align: right;">[14th December, 1952]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to introduce legislation declaring forgery of a passport or a false statement in an application for a passport to be punishable offences. 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make more effective provision for the prevention of certain offences relating to passports and other travel documents;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title, extent and commencement </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the Passport (Offences) Act, 1952.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh and also applies to all citizens of Bangladesh wherever they may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Definition </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act the word “passport” means and includes any permit, visa or other travel document authorising the holder thereof to travel from Bangladesh to any other country, or from any other country to Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalties for certain offences relating to passport</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) Any person who,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        makes, attests or verifies any statement which he does not know or believe to be true in any document which he knows or has reason to think will be used for obtaining a passport; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        makes use of any statement which he knows or has reason to think to be untrue in any document for obtaining a passport; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        wilfully conceals any fact which under the circumstances he ought to disclose for the purpose of obtaining a passport for himself or another person; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        forges, alters or tampers with any passport or with any document which he knows or has reason to believe will be used for obtaining a passport; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        uses a passport which he knows or has reason to believe to be forged, altered, or tampered with; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         is in wrongful possession for any purpose prejudicial to the interests of the State of a passport not lawfully issued to him; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        traffics in passports;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to two years or with a fine, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Explanation.- A person who bona fide works for an applicant for a passport at the desire of the applicant though it may be for a gain does not traffic in passports within the meaning of this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2[ (2) No Court shall take cognizance of any offence under this section except with the previous sanction in writing of the Government.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_________________________________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, unless otherwise provided, the word “Bangladesh” was substituted for the word “Pakistan” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 Sub-section (2) was substituted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
236	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE POST OFFICE NATIONAL SAVINGS CERTIFICATES ORDINANCE, 1944 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE POST OFFICE NATIONAL SAVINGS CERTIFICATES ORDINANCE, 1944</strong></p><p align="center">(ORDINANCE NO. XLII OF 1944)</p><p align="right">[9th September, 1944]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to make certain provision in respect of Post Office Twelve-Year National Savings Certificates and other classes of Savings Certificates.  1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS an emergency has arisen which renders it necessary to make certain provision in respect of Post Office Twelve-Year National Savings Certificates and other classes of Savings Certificates;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in exercise of the powers conferred by section 72 of the Government of India Act, as set out in the Ninth Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, the Governor-General is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title, application and commencement </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Post Office National Savings Certificates Ordinance, 1944.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It applies to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        Post Office Twelve-Year National Savings Certificates issued in pursuance of the Notification of the Government of India in the Finance Department, No. F. 17(100)-F/43, dated the 4th September, 1943, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        any other classes of savings certificates to which the Government may from time to time by notification in the official Gazette direct that the provisions of this Ordinance shall apply.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Interpretation </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “minor” means a person who is not deemed to have attained his majority under the Majority Act, 1875;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “savings certificate” includes a Post Office Twelve-Year National Savings Certificate referred to in clause (a) of sub-section (2) of section 1 and a savings certificate of any other class to which the provisions of this Ordinance have been applied by a direction in pursuance of clause (b) of that sub-section;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “transfer” means a transfer inter vivos and does not include a transfer by operation of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Restriction of transfer</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Notwithstanding any provision in any enactment or any rule of law for the time being in force to the contrary, no transfer, whether made before or after the commencement of this Ordinance or, as the case may be, before or after the making of a direction in pursuance of clause (b) of sub-section (2) of section 1, of a savings certificate shall be valid without the previous consent in writing of an officer of the Post Office authorised by general or special order of the Government in that behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Payment on death of holder of savings certificate</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) If a person dies and is at the time of his death the holder of a savings certificate, payment of the sum for the time being due thereon may be made in the manner provided in the Government Savings Banks Act, 1873, for the payment of deposits belonging to the estates of deceased person, and the provisions of section 4 to 9 of the said Act shall apply accordingly as if the holder of the savings certificate were a depositor in a Government Savings Bank and the sum for the time being due on the certificate were a deposit in such a Bank:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that in such application section 8 of the said Act shall be construed as if the reference therein to three thousand 2[ Taka] were a reference to the amount of the maximum holding of savings certificates prescribed in the rules made or deemed to have been made under this Ordinance applicable to the particular savings certificate:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided further that-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the power conferred by the said provisions on the Secretary of a Government Savings Banks shall be exercisable by the Postmaster-General for the area within which the post office of issue of such savings certificate is situated or if that area is in 3[ India or Pakistan], by the Postmaster-General for such area in 4[ Bangladesh] as the Government may by a general or special order specify in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        where in any one case payment is to be made of savings certificates issued from more post offices than one, the said powers shall be exercisable by the Postmaster-General for the area in which any of the said post offices is situated.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall be deemed to require any person to accept payment of the amount due on a savings certificate before it has reached maturity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Holdings by or on behalf of minors</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. Notwithstanding any provision in any enactment or any rule of law for the time being in force to the contrary,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) a minor may apply for and hold savings certificates and any person may apply for and hold savings certificates on behalf of a minor;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        where any certificate is held by or on behalf of a minor, the minor shall, whether the certificate was applied for and issued before or after the commencement of this Ordinance or, as the case may be, before or after the making of a direction in respect of such certificate in pursuance of clause (b) of sub-section (2) of section 1, be bound by the provisions of this Ordinance and of any rules made or deemed to have been made thereunder applicable to such savings certificate and by the terms of any declaration made by the applicant for the certificate in pursuance of the said rules;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3)        payment of the sum for the time being due on a savings certificate held by or on behalf of a minor may be made-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to him personally, if he himself applied for the certificate, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        for the use of the minor, if the application for the certificate was made by any person other the minor,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         to any such person, being a parent of the minor or guardian of his property, as may be nominated in that behalf in the form of application, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        if no such nomination has been made, to any guardian of the property of the minor appointed by a competent Court, or where no such guardian has been so appointed, to either parent of the minor, or where neither parent is alive, to any other guardian of the minor,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and the receipt of the minor or, as the case may be, of his parent or guardian for any sum paid under this clause shall be a sufficient discharge thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) The Government may by notification in the official Gazette make rules relating to any class of savings certificate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for the application for, the issue, maximum limits of holding and discharge of, and conditions as to interest or discount relating to, any class of savings certificate, and may also provide-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        that where any such maximum limits of holdings are exceeded, no interest shall be payable on the amount of such excess;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        that if any interest has been paid on any amount of such excess, it shall be recoverable as an arrear of land-revenue or in such other manner as the rules may prescribe.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All rules relating to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the Post Office Twelve-Year National Savings Certificates in force at the commencement of this Ordinance,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) any other class of savings certificate in force at the time when a direction in pursuance of clause (b) of sub-section (2) of section 1 is made in respect thereof-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall, so far as they are not inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance, continue in force until they are duly rescinded or amended, and shall be deemed to have been made under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_________________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Ordinance, word “Government” was substituted for the words “Central Government” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word “Taka” was substituted for the word “rupees” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The words “India or Pakistan” were substituted for the word “India” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The word “Bangladesh” was substituted for the word “Pakistan” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
237	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE PREVENTION OF CORRUPTION ACT, 1947</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE PREVENTION OF CORRUPTION ACT, 1947</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. II OF 1947)</p><p align="right">[11th March, 1947]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act for the more effective prevention of bribery and corruption.        1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make more effective provision for the prevention of bribery and corruption;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title and extent</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh and applies to all citizens of Bangladesh and persons in the service of 2[ the Republic] wherever they may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Interpretation</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. For the purposes of this Act, “public servant” means a public servant as defined in section 21 of the Penal Code and includes an employee of any corporation or other body or organisation set by the Government and includes a Chairman, Vice-Chairman, Member, Officer or other employee of a local 3[ authority], or a Chairman, Director, Managing Director, Trustee, Member, Officer or other employee of any corporation, or other body or organisation constituted or established under any law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Offences under sections 161 and 165 of the Penal Code to be cognizable offences</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. An offence punishable under section 161, 162, 163, 164, 165 or 165-A of the Penal Code shall be deemed to be a cognizable offence for the purposes of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained therein.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Presumption where public servant accepts gratification other than legal remuneration</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) Where in any trial of an offence punishable under section 161 or section 165 of the Penal Code, it is proved that an accused person has accepted or obtained, or has agreed to accept or attempted to obtain, for himself or for any other person, any gratification (other than legal remuneration) or any valuable thing from any person, it shall be presumed unless the contrary is proved that he accepted or obtained, or agreed to accept or attempted to obtain, that gratification or that valuable thing, as the case may be, as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in the said section 161, or, as the case may be, without consideration or for a consideration which he knows to be inadequate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Where in any trial of an offence punishable under section 165A of the Penal Code it is proved that any gratification (other than legal remuneration) or any valuable thing has been given or offered to be given or attempted to be given by any accused person, it shall be presumed, unless the contrary is proved, that he gave or offered to give or attempted to give that gratification or that valuable thing, as the case may be, as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in section 161 of the said Code, or, as the case may be, without consideration or for a consideration which he knew to be inadequate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-sections (1) and (2), the Court may decline to draw the presumption referred to in either of the said sub-sections if the gratification or thing aforesaid is, in its opinion, so trivial that no inference of corruption may fairly be drawn.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Criminal misconduct</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) A public servant is said to commit the offence of criminal misconduct-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) if he accepts or obtains or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain from any person for himself or for any other person, any gratification (other than legal remuneration) as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in section 161 of the Penal Code, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        if he accepts or obtains or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain for himself or for any other person any valuable thing without consideration or for a consideration which he knows to be inadequate, from any person whom he knows to have been, or to be, or to be likely to be concerned in any proceeding or business transacted or about to be transacted by him, or having any connection with the official functions of himself or of any public servant to whom he is subordinate, or from any person whom he knows to be interested in or related to the person so concerned, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        if he dishonestly or fraudulently misappropriates or otherwise converts for his own use any property entrusted to him or under his control as a public servant or allows any other person so to do, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) if he, by corrupt or illegal means or by otherwise abusing his position as public servant, obtains or attempts to obtain for himself or for any other person any valuable thing or pecuniary advantage, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) if he, or any of his dependents, is in possession, for which the public servant cannot reasonably account, of pecuniary resources or of property disproportionate to his known sources of income.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Explanation.- In this clause “dependent” in relation to a public servant, means his wife, children and step-children, parents, sisters and minor brothers residing with and wholly dependent on him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any public servant who commits or attempts to commit criminal misconduct shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or 4[ with both, and the pecuniary resources or property to which the criminal misconduct relates may also be confiscated to the State].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) In any trial of an offence punishable under sub-section (2) the fact that the accused person or any other person on his behalf is in possession, for which the accused person cannot satisfactorily account, of pecuniary resources or property disproportionate to his known sources of income may be proved, and on such proof the Court shall presume, unless the contrary is proved, that the accused person is guilty of criminal misconduct and his conviction therefore shall not be invalid by reason only that it is based solely on such presumption.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The provisions of this section shall be in addition to, and not in derogation of, any other law for the time being in force, and nothing contained herein shall exempt any public servant from any proceeding which might, apart from this section, be instituted against him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5[ 5A. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 no officer below the rank of Inspector of Police shall investigate any offence punishable under any of the sections of the Penal Code mentioned in section 3 or any offence punishable under section 5 without an order of a Magistrate of the first class or make any arrest therefore without a warrant.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[Omitted]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. [Previous sanction necessary for prosecution.- Omitted by section 5 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1953 (Act No. XXXVII of 1953).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Accused person to be competent witness</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. Any person charged with an offence punishable under section 161 or section 165 of the Penal Code or under sub-section (2) of section 5 of this Act shall be a competent witness for the defence and may give evidence on oath in disproof of the charges made against him or any person charged together with him at the same trial:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that -</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) he shall not be called as a witness except on his own request,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) his failure to give evidence shall not be made the subject of any comment by the prosecution or give rise to any presumption against himself or any person charged together with him at the same trial,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        he shall not be asked, and if asked shall not be required to answer, any question tending to show that he has committed or been convicted of any offence other than the offence with which he is charged, or is of bad character, unless-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         the proof that he has committed or been convicted of such offence is admissible evidence to show that he is guilty of the offence with which he is charged, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        he has personally or by his pleader asked questions of any witness for the prosecution with a view to establish his own good character, or has given evidence of his good character, or the nature or conduct of the defence is such as to involve imputations on the character of the prosecutor or of any witness for the prosecution, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       he has given evidence against any other person charged with the same offence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, the words “Bangladesh”, “Government” and “Penal Code” were substituted for the words “Pakistan”, “Central Government” and “Pakistan Penal Code” respectively by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words “the Republic” were substituted for the word “Government” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The word “authority” was substituted for the words, commas and figures “council as defined in the Basic Democracies Order, 1959, or of a Municipal Committee” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The words “with both, and the pecuniary resources or property to which the criminal misconduct relates may also be confiscated to the State” were substituted for the words “with both” by section 2 of the Prevention of Corruption (Amendment) Act, 1992 (Act No. VIII of 1992)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 Section 5A was inserted by section 5 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1953 (Act No. XXXVII of 1953)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
238	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE PREVENTION OF TRANSFER OF PROPERTY AND REMOVAL OF DOCUMENTS AND RECORDS ACT, 1952 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE PREVENTION OF TRANSFER OF PROPERTY AND REMOVAL OF DOCUMENTS AND RECORDS ACT, 1952</strong></p><p align="center">(EAST BENGAL ACT NO. V OF 1952)</p><p align="right">[30th October, 1952]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to provide against certain difficulties in the way of speedy acquisition of interest in land under the 2[ * * *] State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide against certain difficulties created or sought to be created by certain classes of persons in the way of speedy acquisition of estates, taluks, tenures and other interests in land, under the provisions of the 3[ * * *] State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title, extent and commencement</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.         (1) This Act may be called the 4[ * * *] Prevention of Transfer of Property and Removal of Documents and Records Act, 1952.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall be deemed to have come into force on the 21st day of July, 1951.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2.         In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Collector” means the Collector of a district and includes 5[ * * *] such other officers not below the rank of a Deputy Collector as may be appointed by the Government to discharge all or any of the functions of a Collector under this Act;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “cutchery building” means a building or part of a building which, on the 16th May, 1951, or thereafter, was or is used primarily as office or cutchery for the management including collection of rents and cesses of any estate, taluk, or tenure or as the residence of staff employed in such management, with the land under it and necessary adjuncts thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “transfer” means transfer by private sale, exchange, lease, gift, mortgage or charge; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        all other words and expressions used in this Act and in the 6[ * * *] State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, shall have the same meanings as in that Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Prohibition against transfer of cutchery buildings and certain lands contiguous thereto</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1)    Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any contract, no person shall transfer, without the previous permission of the Collector in writing,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         any cutchery building; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        any land contiguous to any cutchery building which, on the 16th May, 1951, lay vacant and was not used for agricultural purposes; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       any vacant land situated within any hat or bazar.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        Every transfer made in contravention of sub-section (1) shall be null and void.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Provision regarding transfers made between the 16th May, 1951, and the 21st day of July, 1951</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) Any cutchery building or land as is referred to in sub-section (1) of section 3, if transferred by any person between the 16th day of May, 1951, and the 21st day of July, 1951, shall, notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any contract, be deemed to have been re-transferred to such person on the 21st day of July, 1951.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The transferor in respect of such transfer shall be liable to refund to the transferee or his successor-in-interest, the consideration of such transfer; and the amount or value of such consideration shall, on an application of the transferee or his successor-in-interest to the Collector within two years from the 21st day of July, 1951, be recoverable from such transferor as a public demand.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Safeguards against removal of records</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5.         (1) No rent-receiver shall, after the coming into force of this Act, remove or cause to be removed any document or record relating to any estate, taluk, or tenure, to any place outside Bangladesh, or destroy or cause to be destroyed such document or record.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If any document or record as aforesaid has been removed by any rent-receiver before the commencement of this Act to any place outside the Bangladesh, the Collector may serve an order on such rent-receiver directing him to bring back such document or record to Bangladesh within the time specified in such order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) For the purpose of inspection of any document or record relating to any estate, taluk, or tenure, it shall be lawful for the Collector or any officer authorised by him in writing, to enter into or upon any cutchery building or premises, where the Collector or such officer has reason to believe that such document or record has been kept:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no such entry shall be made between sunset and sunrise and without giving two hours' notice to the rent-receiver concerned of his intention to do so.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Before entering into or upon any cutchery building or premises under the provisions of sub-section (3), the Collector or any officer authorised by him may issue a direction upon the rent-receiver to inform him in writing, within the time specified in such direction, the place where such document or record has been kept.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalty</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) If any person has transferred any cutchery building or land in contravention of sub-section (1) of section 3, the Collector may impose on him a fine which may extend to twice the value or amount of the consideration for such transfer and may also pass an order forfeiting such Cutchery building or land to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If any rent-receiver has removed or destroyed or caused to be removed or destroyed any document or record in contravention of sub-section (1) of section 5, or fails to comply with an order under sub-section (2) of that section, the Collector may impose on him a fine which may extend to ten thousand 7[ taka].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The fine imposed under this section shall be recoverable as a public demand.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) When the Collector has passed an order under sub-section (1) forfeiting any cutchery building or land to the Government, it shall be lawful for him to take actual possession thereof, and in doing so, he may use or cause to be used such force as may be necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Appeal and revision</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) An appeal against any order passed by the Collector under sub-section (1) or sub-section (2) of section 6, if presented within thirty days from the date of the order appealed against, shall lie to the 8[ Commissioner of Division].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9[ (2) If no appeal has been preferred under sub-section (1), the Government may, at any time, of its own motion, revise any order passed by the Collector under sub-section (1) or sub-section (2) of section 6.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10[ (2a)The Government may, of its own motion or on application of the aggrieved person made within thirty days from the date of the order, revise any order passed by the 11[ Board of Land Administration] on appeal under sub-section (1).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12[ (3) An order of the Government passed under sub-section (2) or sub-section (2a) shall be final.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Public servant</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. Any person empowered to perform any function under this Act shall be deemed to be a public servant within the meaning of section 21 of the 13[ * * *] Penal Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Indemnity</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) No suit or legal proceeding shall lie against the Government in respect of anything which is, in good faith, done or intended to be done under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No suit, prosecution or legal proceeding shall lie against any person in respect of anything which is, in good faith, done or intended to be done under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. [Repeal and saving.- Omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11.       The Government may make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Act</p><p style="text-align: justify;">______________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, unless otherwise provided, the words “Bangladesh” and “Government” were substituted for the words “East Pakistan” or “the Province of East Pakistan” and “Provincial Government” respectively by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words “East Bengal” were omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The words “East Bengal” were omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The words “East Bengal” were omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The words “a Subdivisional Officer and” were omitted by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 The words “East Bengal” were omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 The word “taka” was substituted for the word “rupees” by section 3 and the Second Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 The words “Commissioner of Division” were substituted for the word “Government” by section 2 and the Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Amending) Ordinance, 1976 (Ordinance No. IX of 1976)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 Sub-section (2) was substituted by Article 3 and the Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Repealing and Amending) Order, 1973 (President's Order No. 12 of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10 Sub-section (2a) was inserted by section 2 and the Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Amending) Ordinance, 1976 (Ordinance No. IX of 1976)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11 The words “Board of Land Administration” were substituted for the words “Commissioner of Division” by section 4 and the Schedule of the Laws (Amendment) Ordinance, 1982 (Ordinance No. XLI of 1982)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12 Sub-section (3) was substituted by section 2 and the Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Amending) Ordinance, 1976 (Ordinance No. IX of 1976)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13 The word “Pakistan” was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
239	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE PROTECTION AND CONSERVATION OF FISH ACT, 1950 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE PROTECTION AND CONSERVATION OF FISH ACT, 1950</strong></p><p align="center">(EAST BENGAL ACT NO. XVIII OF 1950)</p><p align="right">[18th May, 1950]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to provide for the protection and conservation of fish in 1[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the protection and conservation of fishes in 2[ Bangladesh];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title, extent and commencement </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the 3[ * * *] Protection and Conservation of Fish Act, 1950.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of 4[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force on such date as the 5[ * * *] Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[ 2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) “Current Jal” means fishing net made of monofilament synthetic nylon fibre of different mesh sizes;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        “Fish” includes all cartilaginous, bony fishes, prawn, shrimp, amphibians, tortoise, turtles, crustacean animals, molluscs, echinoderms and frogs at all stages in their life history;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3)        “Fishery” means any water body, natural or artificial, open or closed, flowing or stagnant (such as river, haor, baor, beel, floodplain, canal etc.) where activities for growing fish, or for conservation, development, demonstration, breeding, exploitation or disposal of fish or of living organisms related to such activities are undertaken, but does not include an artificial aquarium of fish used as decorative article, pond or tank;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) “Fishery Officer” means any person whom, the Government or any officer empowered by the Government in this behalf, may appoint to carry out all or any of the purposes of this Act or to do anything required by this Act or by any rule made thereunder to be done by such officer:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, no police officer shall be so empowered;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5)        “Fishing net” means the nets which are specially meant for catching different species of fishes from water bodies and it is one type of fishing gear made of different types of yarns including synthetic yarns of different mesh sizes other than Current Jal. The common tanning materials of net are fruit of gab (Diospyros embryopteris) bark of Goran (Ceriops roxburghiana) and Coal-tar;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6)        “Fixed engine” means any net, cage, trap or other contrivance for catching fish, fixed in the earth or made stationary in any other way.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) The 7[ * * *] Government may make rules for the purposes hereinafter in this section mentioned.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8[ (2) The Government may, by notification, apply such rules or any of them to any water or waters.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Such rules may-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        prohibit or regulate all or any of the following matters, that is to say,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         the erection and use of fixed engines;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        the construction, temporary or permanent, of weirs, dams, bunds, embankments and other structures;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       the use or method of operation of any kind of 9[ fishing net] and the size of the mesh of any 10[ fishing net];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11[ (iv) the manufacture, import, marketing, carrying, transporting or possessing of such fishing nets, traps, gears and other contrivances as may be specified in the rules;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        prohibit the destruction of, or any attempt to destroy, fishes by explosives, gun, bow and arrow in inland water or within coastal territorial waters;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        prohibit the destruction of, or any attempt to destroy, fishes by the poisoning of waters or the depletion of fisheries by pollution by trade effluents or otherwise;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        prescribe the seasons during which the killing or catching of fishes of any prescribed species shall be prohibited;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        prescribe a minimum size below which no fish of any prescribed species shall be killed or sold; 12[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         prohibit all fishing in all waters or in any specified waters for a specified period 13[ ;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        prohibit the destruction of or any attempt to destroy fishes by drying or dewatering of any fishery:]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the 14[ * * *] Government may for the purpose of pisciculture, collection of data and scientific investigation for biological study on fish permit the catching of fishes in any closed season or in any prohibited water or below the prescribed minimum size and disposal thereof subject to the condition of the licence issued for the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15[ (4) In making any rule under this section, the Government may provide for-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the seizure, removal and forfeiture of any fixed engine 16[ , finishing net, Current Jal] or any other contrivance erected or used for fishing in contravention of the rules;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the forfeiture of any fishes taken by means of any such fixed engine 17[ , finishing net, Current Jal] or any other contrivance; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">18[ (c) the procedure for disposal of forfeited fixed engine, fishing net 19[ , Current Jal] or other contrivance or forfeited fish.]]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The power to make rules is subject to the condition of previous publication; and the date to be specified under clause</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) of 20[ section 23 of the General Clauses Act, 1897,] shall not be less than two months from the date on which the draft of the proposed rules was published.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) All such rules shall be published in the official Gazette and shall, unless some later date is appointed, come into force on the date of such publication.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to prohibit sale of fish</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The 21[ * * *] Government may, by notification, prohibit for a specified period the 22[ catching, carrying, transporting, offering, exposing or possession] for sale or barter of fishes below the prescribed size of any prescribed species throughout 23[ Bangladesh] or any part thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Prohibition about Current Jal</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">24[ 4A. (1) No person shall manufacture, fabricate, import, market, store, carry, transport, own, possess or use Current Jal.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whoever has in his possession Current Jal, shall, within 45 (forty-five) days of coming into force of this provision, surrender such Current Jal to the nearest police station, Office of the Fishery Officer or Office of the Upazilla Nirbahi Officer, and during that period an existing possession of Current Jal by any person shall not be deemed to be an offence.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalties</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">25[ 5. (1) The breach of any rule made under section 3 or of any prohibition notified under section 4 shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than one year and may extend to two years, or with fine which may extend to five thousand Taka, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The breach of any prohibition, described in section 4A, in connection with-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) manufacture, fabrication, import, marketing or storing of Current Jal by any person shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than three years and may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to ten thousand Taka; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) carrying, transporting, owning, possession or use of Current Jal by any person shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than one year and may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to five thousand Taka, or with both.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to confiscate</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">26[ 5A. When any person is convicted of an offence punishable under this Act or the rules made under this Act, the Court, before which he is convicted, shall direct that, any article or thing used or intended to be used in the commission of such offence, be confiscated.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Arrest without warrant for offence under the Act</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) Any person, specially empowered by the 27[ * * *] Government in this behalf, may arrest without warrant any person committing a breach of any rule under section 3 or any prohibition notified 28[ under section 4 and 4A respectively]-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) if the name and address of the person are unknown to him, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        if the person declines to give his name and address or if there is reason to doubt the accuracy of the name and address, if given.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A person arrested under this section may be detained until his name and address have been correctly ascertained:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no person so arrested shall be detained longer than may be necessary for bringing him before a Magistrate or to the nearest police-station according to the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, it will be lawful for the officer-in-charge of a police-station to detain a person produced before him under the preceding sub-section till he is produced before the Magistrate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">29[ (4) All Fishery Officers empowered by the Government shall have the same powers of search, seizure and investigation in respect of an offence under this Act as a police officer of the rank of Sub-Inspector; and any police officer, shall be destroyed after the lapse of 30 days, if in the meantime no one claims the same or otherwise initiates any other proceeding regarding his lawful claim thereto.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cognizance, trial etc of offences</p><p style="text-align: justify;">30[ 7. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898)-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        an offence under this Act shall be a cognizable offence within the meaning of that Code;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        no court shall take cognizance of such offence except on the complaint or a report of a fishery officer or of a police officer not below the rank of Sub-Inspector;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">31[ (c) no Court other than of a Metropolitan Magistrate or Magistrate of the first class shall try an offence under this Act; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) A Court trying an offence, except an offence under clause (a) of sub-section (2) of section (5), under this Act may try the offence summarily in accordance with the procedure laid down in the said Code for summary trial.]]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Officers to be deemed public servants</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. All persons empowered to perform any functions under this Act shall be deemed to be public servants within the meaning of section 21 of the 32[ * * *] Penal Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Indemnity</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against any person empowered to perform any function under this Act for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[Omitted]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. [Repeal.- Omitted by section 11 of the Protection and Conservation of Fish (Amendment) Ordinance, 1982 (Ordinance No. LV of 1982).]</p><p style="text-align:
